Title.evidence: Recovery from surgery is quicker in the postpartum period and this may reflect oxytocin action in the spinal cord.

Trial_Design.evidence: Ninety-eight individuals undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty were randomized to receive either intrathecal oxytocin, 100 μg, or saline.

Participants.evidence: Ninety-eight individuals undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty were randomized to receive either intrathecal oxytocin, 100 μg, or saline.

Intervention.evidence: Ninety-eight individuals undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty were randomized to receive either intrathecal oxytocin, 100 μg, or saline.

Objective.evidence: We hypothesized that intrathecal injection of oxytocin would speed recovery from pain and disability after major surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Modelled pain trajectory, the primary analysis, did not differ between groups, either in pain on day of hospital discharge.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-eight individuals undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty were randomized.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Ninety patients received intrathecal oxytocin (n=44) or saline (n=46) and were included in the analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Modelled pain trajectory, the primary analysis, did not differ between groups, either in pain on day of hospital discharge, [intercept: −0.1 (95%CI: −0.8 to 0.6), p = 0.746], or in reductions over time, [slope: 0.1 pain units per log of time (95%CI: 0 to 0.2), p = 0.057].

Harms.evidence: There were no study drug-related adverse effects.

Funding.evidence: The study was stopped early due to lack of funding.
